importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Susan Stamberg began hosting 'All Things Considered' in 1972, making her the first woman to host a national news program, breaking gender barriers in broadcast journalism.
Stamberg hosted a two-hour radio call-in program with President Jimmy Carter from the Oval Office in 1979, showcasing her unique role in bridging public engagement and political discourse.
Stamberg received a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame in 2020, highlighting her cultural influence beyond news broadcasting into entertainment and public recognition.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: This period marks the rise of NPR and the establishment of Susan Stamberg as a foundational figure in public radio, especially through her role in shaping the tone and style of 'All Things Considered'.
Her 14-year tenure on 'All Things Considered' and later roles on 'Weekend Edition Sunday' and 'Morning Edition' demonstrate her lasting impact on public media over nearly five decades.

keyTakeAways: Susan Stamberg was the first woman to host a national news program on American radio, breaking gender norms in broadcast journalism.
She played a pivotal role in shaping the conversational, accessible style of NPR’s programming, helping to establish a new model of public radio journalism.
Stamberg co-founded the concept of 'founding mothers' in public media, representing a shift from traditional male-dominated narratives to inclusive, diverse leadership.
She hosted a historic Oval Office call-in program with President Jimmy Carter in 1979, demonstrating public engagement and democratic participation through media.
She interviewed high-profile figures such as Rosa Parks, James Baldwin, and Nancy Reagan, contributing to public awareness and cultural discourse.
Stamberg’s legacy includes influencing the tone and structure of public radio, particularly through the Sunday puzzle feature with Will Shortz, which mirrored the experience of a Sunday newspaper.
She received a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame in 2020, recognizing her broad cultural influence beyond journalism.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Susan Stamberg, the first woman to host a national news program on National Public Radio (NPR), has died at age 87. A founding mother of NPR, she hosted 'All Things Considered' from 1972 to 1986, helping shape the network’s conversational, inclusive style by rejecting the rigid, performative norms common among female broadcasters of her time. She also played a key role in launching the Sunday puzzle feature with Will Shortz, creating a format that blended news, culture, and entertainment. Stamberg interviewed major cultural and political figures, including President Jimmy Carter, Rosa Parks, James Baldwin, and Nancy Reagan. Her legacy includes pioneering gender-inclusive leadership in media, coining the term 'founding mothers' for women instrumental in public radio’s creation, and receiving recognition through the National Radio Hall of Fame and a Hollywood Walk of Fame star in 2020.
title: Susan Stamberg, first woman to host a national news program, dies at age 87
